clean_content:
Definition / general

* Benign fibrous proliferation of the oral cavity mucosa with distinct stellate fibroblasts

Essential features

* Fibrous nodule that most commonly presents on the gingiva and can have a papillary appearance* Histologic features include large, plump stellate fibroblasts in the superficial connective tissue* Treatment is conservative excision and recurrence is rare

ICD coding

* ICD-10: benign neoplasm of mouth
  + [D10.0](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/D10-D36/D10-/D10.0) - benign neoplasm of lip+ [D10.1](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/D10-D36/D10-/D10.1) - benign neoplasm of tongue+ [D10.39](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/D10-D36/D10-/D10.39) - benign neoplasm of other parts of mouth

Epidemiology

* 2 - 5% of all oral benign fibrous growths ([Neville: Oral and Maxillofacial Pathology, 4th Edition, 2015](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1455770523/pathologyoutl-20))* Increased frequency in ([Case Rep Dent 2014;2014:864512](24511398)):
    + Patients' first to third decade+ Caucasians

Sites

* Most common location is the gingiva followed by the tongue, palate, buccal mucosa and lip ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol 1982;53:582](6954437))

Pathophysiology

* Fibrous proliferation generally considered to be reactive process ([Braz J Otorhinolaryngol 2019;85:399](29705120), [Case Rep Dent 2014;2014:864512](24511398))* Giant cell fibroma shows limited growth potential, local recurrence would be considered exceptional and microscopic appearance is indistinguishable from nonneoplastic retrocuspid papilla; on balance, some authors have suggested the possibility that the lesion represents a neoplasm ([Acta Histochem 2016;118:451](27132705), [Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:71](30693457))

Etiology

* Unclear etiology but less likely to be associated with chronic mild trauma ([Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:71](30693457))

Clinical features

* Dome shaped sessile or pedunculated fibrous nodule* Surface may be smooth, pebbly, bosselated, nodular or papillary* Most lesions are less than 1 cm in diameter ([Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:71](30693457))* Asymptomatic unless secondarily traumatized

Diagnosis

* Definitive diagnosis is made on histopathology

Prognostic factors

* Excellent prognosis and recurrence is rare

Case reports

* 7 year old boy with a pedunculated soft tissue nodule on the mandibular gingiva ([J Oral Maxillofac Res 2013;4:e5](24422028))* 19 year old man with a small growth on the tip of the tongue ([Case Rep Dent 2014;2014:864512](24511398))* 30 year old man with a growth on gingiva in the retromolar area ([J Oral Maxillofac Pathol 2017;21:429](29391720))* 40 year old man with a sessile mass of the buccal mucosa ([J Dent Sci 2021;16:552](33384848))

Treatment

* Conservative surgical excision

Clinical images

Contributed by Sarah H. Glass, D.D.S.  

[![Bosselated gingival mass](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitygiantcellfibromaClinGlass1.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitygiantcellfibromaClinGlass1.jpg)

Bosselated gingival mass

[![Small tongue mass](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitygiantcellfibromaClinGlass2.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitygiantcellfibromaClinGlass2.jpg)

Small tongue mass

Gross description

* Firm tan nodule with white cut surface

Gross images

Contributed by Sarah H. Glass, D.D.S.  

[![Dome shaped mass](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitygiantcellfibromaGrossGlass1.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitygiantcellfibromaGrossGlass1.jpg)

Dome shaped mass

[![White cut surface](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitygiantcellfibromaGrossGlass2.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitygiantcellfibromaGrossGlass2.jpg)

White cut surface

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Varying numbers of large, plump angular and stellate fibroblasts that may demonstrate multiple nuclei in the superficial connective tissue ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol 1974;37:374](4521457))* Proliferation of collagen bundles* Overlying surface epithelium with narrow and elongated epithelial rete ridges* Absence of inflammation

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Sarah H. Glass, D.D.S.  

[![Nodular fibrous proliferation](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitygiantcellfibromaMicroGlass1.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitygiantcellfibromaMicroGlass1.jpg)

Nodular fibrous proliferation

[![Elongated rete ridges](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitygiantcellfibromaMicroGlass2.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitygiantcellfibromaMicroGlass2.jpg)

Elongated rete ridges

[![Stellate fibroblasts](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitygiantcellfibromaMicroGlass3.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitygiantcellfibromaMicroGlass3.jpg)

Stellate fibroblasts

[![Multinucleated fibroblasts](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitygiantcellfibromaMicroGlass4.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitygiantcellfibromaMicroGlass4.jpg)

Multinucleated fibroblasts

Positive stains

* [Vimentin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsvimentin.html)

Negative stains

* [S100](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainss100.html), [GFAP](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsgfap.html), [neurofilament](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsneurofilament.html), [desmin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsdesmin.html), [SMA](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsalphasmoothmuscleactin.html), [CD31](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd31.html), [CD68](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd68.html) ([J Oral Pathol Med 1994;23:284](7523665))

Sample pathology report

* Oral cavity, excisional biopsy:
  + Giant cell fibroma

Differential diagnosis

* **Retrocuspid papillae** ([Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:71](30693457)):
  + Normal anatomic structure, therefore clinicopathologic correlation required+ Histopathologically identical to giant cell fibroma* [Oral squamous papilloma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitysquamouspapilloma.html):
    + Epithelial proliferation with koilocytes related to low risk human papillomavirus* [Verruciform xanthoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityverruciformxanthoma.html):
      + Foam cells in the superficial connective tissue with overlying clefts of orange keratin* [Irritation fibroma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityirritationfibroma.html):
        + Reactive fibrous proliferation with chronic inflammation and without large stellate fibroblasts* Other clinically noted common masses of the gingiva include [pyogenic granuloma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitypyogenicgranuloma.html), [peripheral ossifying fibroma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityperipheralossifyingfibroma.html) and [peripheral giant cell granuloma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityperipheralgiantcellgranuloma.html):
          + Diagnosis made with histopathologic examination
